40770628.review:
[code][h1]An overhyped game that doesn't live up to the hype,[/h1] [i][b]tattletail[/b][/i] achieves it's goal at being a horror game, but soon becomes more annoying than scary with the constant jumpscares, predictable AI, and, the main feature of the game, taking care of a needy knockoff furby while completing short, rediculous tasks. Infact, I died more times from the tattletail whining about food or needing to be groomed, than I did by player error.

 Not to mention, if you go specificly looking for bugs, you WILL find them. For example, I found that jumping on the roof from the doghouse, and jumping on a fence to walk to the fence around the entire house, can lead you to a spot where you can jump off of the map. It's extremely easy, and I'm not even sure it's been fixed. Not to mention, I found myself getting jumpscared through walls very often. 

If this game was redone from scratch, and many things fixed/removed/explained (Such as the neglectant mother), I feel that the hype that this game got would be built back up again, and this time, deserved.

[u]Also,[/u] I understand that you can't expect a perfect game from $5, but the game recieved should atleast be polished, and ready for release, rather than feeling like an unfinished build of the game. [u]Infact,[/u] the free update DLC [i][b](The kalidescope update)[/b][/i] feels more like a finished product than the full game, which [u][b]I PAID[/b][/u] for.

[i]I wouldn't say that this is a terrible game,[/i] but it's mediocre at best, and it [b]needs[/b] more free/paid dlc to keep not only the community, but the game, too, fresh, and running.

Overall, the price should be lowered, [i][u]or removed entirely,[/u][/i] the game needs to be reworked, to get a large bug fix update, and the free update dlc should be extended, and revamped, and the price tag should be added to [b]IT[/b], in my opinion.[/code]

39784951.review:
Tattletail
it's

me。

首先这游戏吸引我是因为看到了基萌markiplier的实况，虽然无论视频还是游戏本体都完全没有中文。
但Tattletail（简称TT）真的好可爱，点燃了我不买不罢休彻夜难眠的欲♂火（误

[b]来说下游戏后的经验，以下会涉嫌剧透。观看需慎重！[/b]

这个游戏的机制非常简单，
持有TT的时候满足他随着时间消耗的三项指标，在黑暗的地区保持亮度，
同时做到在mama追击的时候不发出“过多”的，或“不合时宜”的噪音。
————————————————————————————————————————————————
[h1]【mama】[/h1]
只有当mama追击玩家过程中才需要警惕，其余的时候多大的噪音都可以完全不介意。
追击开始的讯号是巨大的电流声和熄灭的场景照明，同时伴有压抑的BGM循环。
追击结束讯号是清脆的提示音和闪烁后恢复的照明。
以及mama会瞬移，不要想着被追击的时候远远的把mama甩在身后找个死角躲起来。
[strike]你会被踢爆屁股的我跟你讲。[/strike]

[h1]【三项指标】[/h1]
当TT的电池，饥饿，清洁中任何一项需求降低到空都会导致TT开始吵闹发出大的噪声。
这个时候无需考虑过多立刻按住shift开始狂奔到充电机座/冰箱/刷子旁边。毕竟快速奔跑发出的声音根本盖不过TT，
运气好，和需求满足点的位置相近，或者mama不在附近的情况下你还是可以挽回局面然后悄悄溜走的！

三项指标中电池消耗最慢，补充的速度也是最慢的。如果电池指标未能即时满足会导致毁灭性后果233333
饥饿则是消耗与补充都最快要勤看指标，离冰箱近就赶紧喂一口吧。
清洁消耗与补充速度都适中。

[h1]【手电筒】[/h1]
手电筒摇晃6次大概充满，亮度只摇一次下降极快 但可以在mm靠近不贴身的情况下不被察觉的让TT乖乖闭嘴~

手电筒粗略的照射到mama所在方位就会闪烁并且快速消耗亮度和手电持续时间，如果快速移开手电则不会彻底熄灭。
当听见轻微持续的摩擦声时可以用这个方法判断方位。

而直视mama在的方位则会在非常短的时间内关闭手电并让mama察觉你所在的位置向你靠近，
在找蜡烛的关卡可以用这个方法同时熄灭手电并把mama吸引到开阔的位置自己偷偷溜出去。
胆子大点赌一把比被逼到角落让mama爆锤一顿好多了。

手电完全熄灭的时候可以直接看见mama的红色大眼睛，mama的视线会保持在你所在的位置不用担心绕道后面就看不见了
只要不跑步，没有携带TT的情况下不开手电反而是安全的。
————————————————————————————————————————————————
总之 难度适中吧，初次接触这类型游戏的玩家可能会被狭窄压抑的场景和过于少量的提示所营造出的未知恐惧吓得满地图乱躲
但摸清了规律（或者有足够的运气）就可以在七八次阵亡以内破关主线。
因为看不懂英文导致更新的剧情还未尝试。

建模算不上精细却也不违和，有故意做旧游戏广告赚一票菲比情怀党的嫌疑。
找彩蛋作为开启主线真结局的必要手段，要注意有的还未拿的蛋会在剧情进行中被跳过。
例如第一夜和TT一起被从礼物盒中拿出的蛋，将TT收回去后若你不拿会被一起收走。

而有的蛋是随着剧情逐渐解锁的，因为被追击的焦虑想要迅速破关的玩家搜索过一次的地方不会再有心思去二次检查，
特别明显的是在第三（或第四？）夜的捉迷藏游戏中，每次黄色TT捉迷藏上次躲避的位置会留下一只蛋。

但要是找齐了就会特别有成就感。（前提是不借助攻略的情况下....我就是每关都搜索了两次。最后一关藏在袜子里，也藏的太好了吧！！！！）
————————————————————————————————————————————————
以上，不知道啥时候会有汉化补丁和特惠。
但最想要的果然是一个实体的TT布偶啊！
mama也可以啊，感觉非常像加湿器/吹泡泡机！

[strike]官方爸爸快出周边吧。我TM买爆......！[/strike]

39027243.review:
This was a very interesting one to write. Hope you enjoy.

Tattletail provides a wonderful experience for people who are looking for a quick horror game to spare your time. It even has some free DLC, which makes the game 10x better 🤣. This is my review.

I think Tattletail is a wonderful horror game. It bases off of Five Night's at Freddy's, a more popular game franchise than anything I've seen. It has five nights where you take Tattletail and do certain quests or tasks that are very hard and scary to go through. I'm not going to spoil anything for you, but it is a WONDERFUL game to try out. The ending does provide you with happiness, and it also leaves you on a cliffhanger.

First off, the game is scary enough to make your chest bump. It gives you a sign of worry and fear, while also a huge sign of determination to get through the night. When you take the furbish toy, it talks to 1. Annoy you and 2. Make noise. Secretly, there's a devil Tattletail thing given the name "Mama."When you make noise, she listens. And Seeks. She tries to stalk you and when she gets a hold of you...? Well, she's not letting go. 

Secondly, this game's DLC, named "The Kalidoscope" changes your mind about these furbish dolls. It's a pretty interesting DLC for a game this deep. Plus, it's for free. *In Mr. Krab's Voice* Who doesn't like free stuff? So yeah, I think it adds a pretty interesting feel to the game.

I only did two today because I didn't feel like doing a third one and I couldn't come up with one. :/

I hope you all enjoyed. A game like this...you better buy.

-x_Nick300_x

38704339.review:
I gotta say, while I'm late on playing Tattletail, I am not at all new to the game itself.  I've read and seen a playthrough of it when it was first out.  A year later and a huge sale (as of this writing the day after Christmas 2017, on sale for $1.99) it is a fantastic buy for Horror and Adrenaline Junkies like myself.  Even at $5 it's a nice cheap and enjoyable experience.  What I enjoyed msot about this game is the continued trend of "cute...but something isn't right" motiff that this and similar games have, which harkens back to some classic 90s Horror Movies, while Tattletail injects more 90s nostalgia with it being akin to Furbys which plagued Kids for years!

The game utilizes a fantastic ambience of being set at night, with MANY sound cues which trigger Adrenaline and Fear responses, the gameplay also makes use of the "Fight or Flight" drive, when having to deal with the game's Terror: Mama.  A short game, but sweet in my opinion and well worth your time to get the unique world of Tattletail.

36233656.review:
This is a game that had enormous potential from the getgo. It uses the Five Nights at Freddy's model of horror...however it makes the deathly mistake of doing things that made FNAF 2 a chore to play. One of the great things that made FNAF 1 such a joy to play was its ultra creepy visuals, its innovative haunted house feel, and the jumpscares. OMG The jumpscares. This title does one better. It lets you roam around...which is something we've always wanted to do at Freddy's. (and were sort of able to do in a map on Garry's mod). And from the start of tattletail you are immensely creeped out. 

You play an 8 year old child 5 days before christmas who gets out of bed and wanders about the dark house wanting to open his Christmas presents early. We ALL did that and it was an awesome premise. However the premise goes astray and actually starts to tick you off more than bring joy and actual fright. Your present is a talking toy called Tattletail, which is a parody of the 80s (scary) Furby toy that talked. Also TEddy Ruxpin. This name is immensely clever seeing as how the thing that constantly gets you killed is this toy that JUST WON'T SHUT UP! I guess that's the reason. That's the premise. You carry around this toy...and this is where the choices of gameplay borrowed from FNAF2 cause the game to take a wrong turn. In that game you constantly had to wind a musicbox to avoid getting killed by a jester doll...and this caused you to not be able to enjoy doing ANYTHING else (like enjoy the visuals or actually enjoy getting creeped out by the sound and visuals and tension that was there in FNAF 1.) Nope. You had to do what felt like work. Wind the box all game. In this game you have to do three things. None of which make any difference. You have to feed it, brush it and charge it. If you let any of them go too long without doing them, tattletail whines until you do. And this voice is of the fingernails on a chalkboard variety. It never shuts up. And even after you do these things, it whines about other things. It keeps talking. In the early levels you really aren't in any danger at all making you wonder why you have to be so quiet all the time. It never really explains why. Then suddenly you are afraid of another toy called Mama which it doesn't really accurately explain but rather you are instruced via an abstract little scene. Then it becomes like FNAF. Now strangely enough while I found the distant pinpoint eyes great I wasn't as scared by them like say when I saw them in the recent IT. Probably because they were used so much it ceased becoming a fear thing and was more just part of gameplay. And the jumpscare itself (which happens a LOT) never ever shocked me out of my seat like Freddy, Bonnie, and Foxy did. I don't know why. Maybe the music. Maybe the animation wasn't really spooky enough but more satire and funny looking? Perhaps if the shocks were scarier I would not have minded some of the plotholes. Like if this thing is getting me killed, then why don't I put it down. Why don't I call for help? Oh yes that reminds me that there is a door to your mother's room that you can pound on til your fingers bleed and nothing will happen. This smacks of comedy sure. This also smacks of a developer trolling us. No help will come. Where are the parents. We find evidence (I think ) that you are being raised by a single mother. Well the fact that an option says "Knock on Mom's door". But then the logic breaks down night after night, day after day. And is this toy really bullying you? There's fear in that. In fact I was scared from the beginning of this game when I was walking around in a dark house alone and once the furby I mean tattletail carrying started I wanted to shoot myself. Really the fear left because of gameplay and annoyance at that voice. Perhaps a different actor would have made that part more palatable. There is also an extension called Kaleidoscope which continues the story in quite a neat science fictiony way. More logical in its logic than the previous bits. I wanted to get through this game. I wanted better. I wanted more. Everything in my head about this game was scarier than the things that actually happened. And I was stuck doing night four for what seemed an eternity, constantly failing because of something out of my control. I think there's the rub. The game at least is cheapish and when on sale I'd suggest playing it. But there will be fingernails...on a blackboard. And the voiceacting in the expansion gets so much worse. And there's something else audibly irritating to add to all the Tattletailing. Whenever you are making noise, it puts a megaphone icon in the corner of your screen and beeps in a high-pitched, dog-summoning tone until you stop. Does this increase tension? Yes. Does this increase the irritation? Yes. It really feels like the game is nagging you to death.

36069418.review:
Je vám 12 a máte rádi FNAF? Pak i tohle může být vaše další oblíbená hra.

Tattletail je kvalitní horrorovka, která spoléhá na jeden jediný stále dokola opakovaný jumpscare. Poprvé možná trochu povyskočíte, podruhé to s vámi možná mírně hrkne, ale dál už to je prostě stále to samé repetitivní nezajímavé dokola. Dobré maximálně tak pokud chcete udělat video na svůj youtube channel ve kterém budete většinu času neupřímně křičet jak je to všechno strašně creepy. Není. Podívejte se jak to vypadá. Tohle je ještě horší než FNAF, je to vyloženě jenom plyšák, ani ne creepy plyšák, prostě jenom plyšák. Něco čeho se prostě nikdo seriózně bát nemůže. I Mama Tattletail je pouze plyšák, jen se špičatými zuby a svítícíma očima. Oooo, jak strašidelné.

Tattletail je unikátní mix survival horroru a... hlídání dětí. Ano, zatímco se snažíte splnit objektivy, váš Tattletail na vás bude řvát že chce nakrmit, učesat a nebo dobít baterky. Což není žádný creepy plot twist, ale doslova to co říká. Po dobu hry ho tedy budete pravidelně tahat k ledničce, ke kartáči a a nabíječce. Jak je možné že čím víc se Tattletailovi vybíjí baterka tím víc randálu dělá, to je mi záhadou. Velmi logické je také to, že kartáč je nemožné vzít s sebou a musí zůstat tam kde je. Z "Doufám že mě Mama Tattletail nechytí" se tak velmi rychle stane "Drž už konečně hubu ty malej fialovej zmrde". 

Hra vám dokonce vyloženě lže o svých mechanikách. Bude tvrdit že Mama po vás půjde jenom když budete dělat zvuk. Co si myslíte že se stane když si stoupnete doprostřed pokoje, vůbec se nebudete hýbat a zvuk nevydáte ani vy ani ta plyšová koule co máte v ruce? Ano, prohrajete hru. Protože po vás půjde Mama. Dobrá práce hro.

Samozřejmě nesmí chybět klasický tuctový horrorový soundtrack. Kdyby člověk vypnul zvuk tak brzo zapomene že vůbec hraje horrorovou hru. Ale bylo by fajn kdyby náhodné zvuky, které běžně v normálních hrách znamenají že se něco děje nehrály.. náhodně a bez toho aby cokoliv znamenaly.

Na druhou stranu nově přidaný Kaleidoscope Expansion update je zajímavější než samotná hra, nabízí více surrealistické vizuály a dokonce i v rámci možností decentní příběh, což se o základní hře říct nedá.

100% achievementy jsou bez problému zvládnutelné, ale na sbírání vajec pravděpododobně budete potřebovat návod. A možná si ho čtěte než začnete daný level hrát, ať v této hře nemusíte trávit víc času než je nutné.

Stojí to za pět euro? Rozhodně ne. Stálo by to za 0,99€? Eeeeh... diskutabilně. 4/10

35981450.review:
In 1998, when I was eight, my mum took me and my younger brother's furbies, and strategically placed them around her apartment. Mechanical, fuzzy sentries. She had grown tired of he and I sneaking around once the lights were out. Gobbling candy and leftovers and stealthily playing on our Playstation.

Somehow, when we rose that night, thinking our mum was asleep, the two of us failed to notice the animatronic creatures were missing from our room. We carefully padded through the apartment, giggling like goblins. Only for us to scream at the top of our lungs when a furby lit up on the hall table, and proclaimed its love for us. 

Our mum, needless to say, was not pleased.

Tattletail lets me relive that PTSD-inducing night of childhood terror. Thank the Gaming Gods it exists. It's nigh therapeutic! (And pretty funny too)

35955460.review:
I really expected to lke this game more than I do. The premise is very clever, and the visuals are well-done for a Unity budget title, but the gameplay feels very much like a more free-roam take on Five Nights at Freddy's, which I just don't find particularly interesting or scary. The core gameplay revolves around getting out of bed, finding Tattletail, doing whatever activities the game's objective prompts tell you to do, all while keeping your flashlight charged (which drops way too fast) and keeping Tattletail charged, fed, and groomed (those meters also drop way too fast). If you fail to do so, Tattletail will start making all kinds of noise, and the Tattletail Mama will find you and kill you (with a jump-scare right out of FNAF).

Bottom line, if you're the sort who thinks Five Nights at Freddy's is a neat horror series, and you want to try something new, you'll probably really dig Tattletail. But if you're like me and find managing meters to avoid canned jump-scares a poor excuse for horror, I'd recommend you stay away from this one.

35770731.review:
[h1]Creepy and adorable[/h1]

It's 5 days before Christmas and you're a child who wants to open his present early: each night you'll play with your new Tattletail but then you'll have to help it defeat the demonic Mama. She will chase you and she will find you by hearing the noise you make when recharging the flashlight or the noise Tattletail makes because of its needs (battery, feed, groom, light). Mama can teleport and turn off your flashlight when you point it at her, and when she appears the house goes dark so you will only be able to see her red glowing eyes.

The furry toy that you'll have to bring with you is cute and amusing with its pesky but funny voice, the mechanical movement of eyes and mouth, and the noises it makes when the battery is empty. The Tattletails are spooky as well: they are somehow animated and they do things like playing hide-and-seek... But you never see them move.

The map is small and there aren't many things you can do, so the game can be beaten in one hour (but you need to collect all the eggs to get the good ending). It's not as scary as [i]Five Nights at Freddy's[/i] but the gameplay is way better and fairer, and the overall style is more creative and fascinating.

35705037.review:
Wasn't scary in the least. I'd like to recommend this because it's well made and has decent atmosphere, and it definitely brought back memories of the Furby craze, but the narrative just wasn't strong enough to really create that much tension. Without knowing anything about your character except from what you can see in photos, it's extremely hard to care about their fate. With no actual scares for 2/5 of the days depicted, it's hard to be immersed. Most importantly of all, with no difficulty curve, it's almost impossible to find much enjoyment. It's possible to beat the game without dying once as long as you figure things out. Also, whereas a replenishment mechanic might have served to ratchet up the tension in another game, the requirements of your Tattletail just come across as annoying in this one.

The Kaleidoscope mode was an interesting (read: weird) bit of storytelling that did add to the game, but just as before, the consequences didn't seem large enough, the level design was too predictable, and it all just came across as a little flat.

35531182.review:
I got this as a gift and at first, it was pleasing. There was the nostalgia of a toy I never had the chance to own but sure wanted to, and there's the VHS-esque loading screen... end of nostalgia. 
The first level was laughable, and the following couple tasks mildly amusing- and then the "mother" was introduced.
randomly, her red eyes will appear after the lights go out, and from my experience, getting too close causes the screen to freak out a little and if your toy dares make noise... jumpscare insta-death. (I only died once and I wasn't in the line of sight but she was around the corner so I'm not really sure how the death trigger works).
Your furby-knockoff needs a considerable amount of tending to, making the hide-and-seek game go from decent to tedious to annoying very quickly. I stopped after the third round of hide and seek.

Granted, I absolutely hated FNAF, I imagine if you liked those games, you'd like this one. 
The game is very beautiful at first, but the exessive trips to the three recharge stations made the setting less and less enjoyable. The sound the eyes made when moving reminded me very much of toys I had seen at the time that advertised "real moving eyes" so I found that a neat little detail. 

I would not pay for this game myself, but if you have kids who like those sort of jumpscare games or you yourself enjoy anamatronic survival games, I think you might find it worth your money.

I'd give this an in-between vote if I could, because in some ways the game is great for anyone, and for others it only appeals to a very select sort of people.

At the very least, I can attest to the accuracy of this game, as little 8 year old DefiantSentryV recieved his very own Furby on Christmas of 1998, and it was an annoying little creature that talked too much, made horrible grinding noises, and sounded as if it was possessed by a demon on quaaludes whenever the batteries got low. Naturally, I fell in love with it, because I was 8 and easy to please. My poor parents, not so much. When the childlike joy and innocence drained out of me as the years went by, I began to understand why so many parents loathe any kind of toy that doesn't know how to shut the hell up.

This game is essentially owning a Furby all over again. You are tasked with caring for a shrill, fuzzy little machine that tries to be cute while demanding you perform menial tasks for it at an hour in which most people would prefer to sleep. At the same time, you are being stalked by a mother that wants to kill you for running around the house making too much noise when you SHOULD be in bed. You are ultimately just going through the motions to appease the jibbering little monster in hopes that maybe it will shut up and you can finally go to sleep. It's not fun. It's not scary. It's just annoying.

I CAN say that I found the events of Christmas Eve hilarious, so there's that.

35330223.review:
Are you scared of dolls, clowns, animatronics and other memes that people say they're scared of to fit in? Are you the type of person who thinks Five Nights at Freddy's is a good game? Well then this is the game for you! Tattletail is a game about scary furbies. You carry a furby around while it says things like "I love playing with you!", "Me Tattletail!", and, "Give me a treat!" If that doesn't scare you then don't worry, the game will play scary noises like the classic metal wire scraping, the more traditional random piano note, and the modern rythmic thumping to let you know that this is a horror game. This is to let you know that you should be scared, because if you're not braindead then you might notice how mind numbingly boring the game is. 

In Tattletail you carry the furby around and do some objectives that have you running around the house. While you're doing this you have to keep the thing fed, brushed, and charged. If you don't it starts complaining and won't shut up until you satisfy it. Not sure why running out of batteries causes it to make more noise but whatever. You have a flashlight that you have to shake to keep it charged, and you have to shake it roughly every 15 seconds. It makes noise when you shake it. The furby also likes to make noise just for an added layer of annoyance. Occasionally the lights go out and then all these noise mechanics come into play, because the big furby will try to find and kill you. Now the thing can't actually move, it just teleports nearby so all you have to do is move out of it's line of sight and just move back if it teleports again. Supposedly noise attracts it, and at one point the game told me it only attacks if you make noise. So I figured if I just stood on my bed then it would never be able to get me. So I hop on and get into a corner and the thing teleports to the side of the bed, then after a few seconds it killed me. So I guess noise isn't what triggers it. That was the only time I died. 

Anyway I got bored around the 4th level or so. It's just another indie horror game to try and cash in on whatever scary thing is flavor of the month. Technically it's animatronics but I guess nobody's done specifically furbies before, so he gets a C- for originality.

I love this game! 

I really enjoyed the art/graphics/style and the overall simplicity of the mechanics. This is a perfect example of less being so much more. Some games try too hard to scare you and I think this one finds a great balance. I think the price is perfect and I REALLY look forward to more from these Devs.

The story is pretty straight forward with a couple of creepy twists. The atmosphere was decent too. I found myself sufficiently scared of running into Mama since she could be fairly unpredictable. Having headphones really helped me get through some of the more frustrating parts near the end. 

There isn't a lot of replay value once you get all the achievements and complete the free DLC. By that time, a lot of the horror has worn off. So if I play this again, it will probably only be during Halloween or something.

33962209.review:
This game is suprisingly a lot scarier then I expected it to be and all around a very good little indie horror game now I will list my pros and cons

Pros
-Graphics are good not the absolute best ever but still pretty good
-The atmosphere in this game is ok but the feel of this game to me is perfect and fits the game really well
-The Mechanics are very interesting I like how your a small child and all you can do to defend yourself is hide in the darkness and hope to god "Mama" doesn't hear you
-Tattletail the little purple one you hold I really like how he acts you really do need to pay attention to his needs to keep him from blabbering about wanting food, needing to be groomed, or needing to be charged this mechanic is really good and helps make the game tense as hell
-The setting is good not amazing but good it does work for this game and is all around setup really well

Cons
-To avoid "Mama" you need to make no noise and the bad thing is Tattletail will sometimes just randomly say something and if "Mama" is near your screwed and she will kill you this is very annoying
-Christmas Eve the night where you have to move around the basement and break vases while "Mama" is in there with you is very VERY frustrating

Verdict
-Good Graphics and Animations
-Decent Enviornment that fits the game
-Really unique mechanics that make the game tense as all hell
-Tattletail randomly speaking and Christmas Eve are very annoying

**Score 9.1/10**

Absolutely love this game! I've been wanting it since it's release, and was finally able to purchase it to play it myself. The atmosphere is perfect in creating a sense of unease in the player, and it differs the typical run-away-from-the-monster game by presenting the challenge of having to keep Tattletail's needs met at the same time.

I used to have Furbies as a kid that would turn on by themselves continue to make noise long after their batteries were supposedly dead, so I when I first heard about a horror game staring Furby knockoffs... well, I had to play it. Good story, good characters, good gameplay. Highly recommended.

My only complaint? Even with the Kaleidoscope campaign, I really wish that gameplay lasted longer, as I was able to 100% it in only three hours.

Tattletail is a simple horror game based on Furby toys. It's not without its challenges but compared to games like Outlast, Cursed Forest and Amnesia this game is simple. You should be able to play the whole thing in one sitting.  This is a great horror game if you're in the mood for something short and sweet or if you're just getting into horror games and want to start out on something not too extreme.

32008468.review:
[h1][u]Mama Hates You[/u][/h1]

[h1]Overview[/h1]
A hilarious and scary short horror game featuring re-imagined Furbies.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
1. Humorous. After playing, watching and following lots of horror games, ones like this don't scare me anymore. But it DID make me laugh. There's a point where one of the Tattletails actually "tattles" on you, telling Mama where you and your Tattletail are hiding. It cracked me up.

2. Simple, yet tense gameplay

3. A genuinely amusing concept

4. The Tattletails are actually kind of cute, in a syrupy kind of way. Although I did scream SHUT UP a few times, I also chuckled when Tattletail's eyes got really wide and he shook with fear when Mama came around.

5. A comical story

6. It had a FNAF formula, which it improved upon. I don't care for FNAF, but this game was solid.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
1. Wish it was longer. Even with the bonus material. Hopefully more content will be released, because it really is a good time.

2. It made me want to own a Furby. That's not good for anyone involved.

[h1]Conclusions[/h1]
It's definitely worth the purchase if you grew up in the nineties and have serious nostalgia for these things. It's still worth a purchase even if you haven't. Though it was short, it was very entertaining.

31916587.review:
Tattletail är ett första personens skräckutforskningsspel där du spelar som ett ungt barn som utforskar sitt hus under dagarna före och efter julafton. Under denna tid hittar han och öppnar sin tidiga julklapp med sin helt nya tatuering. Detta startar en kedja av händelser där du upptäcker ett band som sätter igång händelserna som uppstår i spelet. Spelet är väldigt slumpmässigt ibland. Det är en blandning mellan ett vänligt barns spel med aspekter av spel som (Slender & Dungeon Nightmares) under hela 1/2 timmars spel, din tatuering kommer att prata med dig och säger slumpmässiga fakta och på många gånger ber dig att "borsta" och " Mata "den. Detta har också effekt på gameplayen som du blir jagad av antagonisten "Mama" som är uppenbarligen mamma till tatuering. Slutet hade jag förvånat och skrattar och samtidigt är det ett intuitivt spel med många konstiga stunder, men väl värt din $ 5,00 om du bestämmer dig för att köpa den. Du får också ett gratis DLC-paket som heter "The Kaleidoscope" som lägger till ytterligare 50 + minuter till ditt spel.

Pro: Frisk ny ta en blandning av skräck och komedi, slät grafik, läskig atmopsphere, gratis DLC

Con: Mamma kan upptäcka dig genom väggar ibland, novell som låter dig undra vad som just hände

Jag ger detta spel en 6/10

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Tattletail is a first-person horror exploration game where you play as a young child exploring his house during the days before and after christmas eve. during this time he finds and opens his early christmas present containing his brand new tattletail. this starts a chain of events where you discover a tape that sets in motion the events that occur in the game. the game is very random at times. it's a mix between a friendly child's game with aspects of games like (Slender & Dungeon Nightmares) throughout your 1/2 hours of gameplay your tattletail will talk to you saying and noting random facts and at many times begging you to 'brush' and 'feed' it. this also has effect on the gameplay as you're being chased by the antagonist 'Mama' who is apparently the mother of the tattletails. the ending had me suprised and laughing and the same time, it's a intuitive game, with many weird moments, but well worth your $5,00 if you decide to buy it. you also get a free DLC package called 'The Kaleidoscope' which adds another 50+ minutes to your game.

Pro's: Fresh new take on a mix of horror and comedy, smooth graphics, scary atmopsphere, free DLC

Con's: Mama can detect you through walls sometimes, short story that leaves you wondering what just happened

I give this game a 6/10

31857911.review:
I for one love this game. It has a great story for all those theorists out there, and it's got the best quality. Like every other game, it has its ups and downs, but I'll recommend for this one because there's only a few details that are bad about it and I'm not known to be a picky pete. 


If you dont know what Tattletail is, well, here's the basics.

You are a 10 year old boy from Florida who lives across from the Waygetter company, the ones who make the toy Baby Talking Tattletail. This young boy, Thomas, is very impatient for christmas to come. So impatient that he can't wait five days or he'll burst! He wakes up in the middle of the night to go downstairs into his basement and find his Christmas gift. Surprise surprise! It's a Baby Talking Tattletail! But this Tattletail won't stay in his box. He goes out to cause mischief and Thomas has to wake himself up every day until Christmas day to make sure that Tattletail gets into no trouble. But Tattletail's mother, Mama Tattletail, is upset about Thomas messing around with her son. The bloodthirsty Mama Tattletail, after two nights of watching Thomas grab and mess with her son, finally lets go of her patience and begins attacking poor Thomas. Now Thomas has two goals: One to keep Talking Tattletail from telling and making problems, and to survive Mama Tattletail's teeth. On Christmas Eve, Tattletail and his brothers decide to tell Thomas to get a ''party'' ready for Mama. But when Thomas gets the finishing touch, the candles, he finds the Tattletail family in a circle, christmas lights strung out on the floor, having some sort of ritual, chanting ''No more mama!'' Still confused, Thomas puts down and lights the candles, rewinding the VHS. Mama tattletail is not impressed and steals the candles so the deed cant be done and hides them in vases. Now Thomas has to survive Mama, deal with the annoyance of Tattletail's voice, AND noisily break the vases to find the candles. Finally he does, relights them for the Tattletail Tribe, and observes their ceremony. But Mama isn't done there. She escapes the banishment by hiding in Tattletail's original box. She comes out right before Thomas wakes up the next day, sneaks up behind him, and gives him a piece of her mind.

Sorry if I just spoiled the game for you.

Anyway, here we go.



Pros:
The 90's vibe is amazing.
The graphics are 10 out of 10.
Mama's design is on point, with all the rips and tears and the red glow in her eyes.
Tattletail looks so adorable <3

Cons:
The camera wildly moves around faster than a normal mouse should.
Tattletail's voice is a disgrace to humanity.
Mama's jumpscare isn't too scary.
On Christmas Eve, it takes you back to the start of the night, which I loathe.


But even with the cons, this game is great and I'd buy it for $20.00! That's $15.00 extra for what I payed for this game, but it deserves more than it gets! I just don't understand why people call it a '
''fnaf rip-off'' because it has nothing to do with FNaF. People think that all horror games are linked to FNaF, and it's sad that games like this don't get enough love just because some kids think that every horror game has to do with sitting on your ass in an office looking at a freaking robotic bear for 6 hours straight. But really, that's all I have to say. I hope this review helped! <3

So, this is one of my scariest games yet, but SCP was definetly the more challenging, besides that they are many pros and cons that i found while playing this magnificent game, each one will have a detailed explanation about why I beleive this.

PROS
The atmosphere was simply fantastic, it kept me on my seat, something most horror games just couldnt coprehend, the sounds and spooky sounds always kept the feeling eerie and creepy, which should always be a Pro for Games like these

The mechanics are also fairly decent and amazing, took me 2 hours to figure it out but in the end, it turned to an easy yet challenging experience that i personally find enjoyable and Reasonable for these type of horror survival games

the enemy is of course, mama tattletail, her voice is by Geneva Hudson, one of the main producers of this game, the way they tuned up her voice to make it sound mechanical was only more of a reason to love this game, simply magnificence and Wonderful.

now with every pro, there is a con

CONS

it got very repetitve, feeding grooming petting running repeat, it got really boring after hours of doing the same thing over and over again.

the sound system is kind of broken, for example, i was completely silent while going to pick up the Yellow tattletail, and i immediatley got jumpscared as soon as i reached the living room, i wasnt making any sounds, and it was completely silence, hopefuly they'll fix this in the Sequel or Prequel

Mama's Jumpscare starting getting repetitve, making it lose its factor and became quite annoying, perhaps change this by adding new animations and adding a different sound effect each jumpscare.

Cons aside, this game was quite entertaining, horrifying, and Fun for the most part, i hope they'll expand the lore and addd maybe a new enemy and a completely different set of mechanics in the Next tattletail game, that concludes this review

Tattletail is perfect for those who want to be scared for an hour while playing a game about furbys. I was too lazy to go past night 3, but I know everything about it. 


Performance/Graphics 8/10

This game peforms well, if your computer is beefy enough and you turn down the resolution. The controls are pretty good, for a game where you walk and look around, interact by left clicking, charge a light by right clicking. Waygetter did a pretty good job for an original horror game.

Gameplay 9/10

You're a sneaky kid, who creaps down into the dark basement and open the presents early. In the big red spotted box is a Baby Talking Tattletail, the modern version of a furby. The commercial doesn't lie, feed him, brush him, and don't let him run out of batteries. Do what he wants while avoiding his really overprotective mother, Mama Tattletail, recalled a year earlier. At the end of the game, banish that mom with a very satanic ritual, and awake to a nice day. Collecting the eggs could determine your fate.

Overall rating 8.5/10
This game has very good gameplay, with ok graphics and performance. I reccomend you try it, and if you get a tattletail in real life, throw it out the window unless it gives you a birth tag.

31228663.review:
I enjoyed this game. It was fun and creepy. If you're a fan of FNaF, this game is definitely for you. One complaint I have is the last night. Without spoiling anything, for the last night you don't have your Tattletail with you, which is 99% of the cause of deaths, which makes the Mama less of a big scary monster and more of an annoyance. Also, another problem is that the game is way too short. The first 3 nights are a tutorial, leaving you with only 2 real nights. However, the short time is worth it because of how creepy Mama is. While there are jumpscares in it which may scare (No pun intended) people away, Mama delivers more than just jumpscares by the way she stalks you. When Mama is near, she makes a whirring noise that will have you running in the opposite direction in hopes of escaping, as well as two glowing red eyes so that you know right where she is. She usually appears right where you want to go, and pausing to do a task while hearing the whirring noise but not seeing her adds to the overall creepy factor. Accompanied by the music that plays when Mama is near adds up to a great monster for a horror game. The game also has secrets and multiple endings, which adds a little more things to do in this small game. Overall, fun game, if you're looking for a quick scare I would recommend it.

EDIT: I have just played the Kaleidoscope campaign. This mode adds more value to the game, and while I didn't like it as much as the normal game, it was still pretty fun. The Kaleidoscope is best played without knowing anything about it so I won't spoil much.
This campaign is WEIRD. If you're expecting a different house with different nights and tasks and new monsters, this is the complete opposite of that. Expect the unexpected when going in. This campaign, while not very scary, has some funny moments and some flat-out STRANGE moments. In terms of scares, there's one chase scene at the end, but it was so strange that I wasn't scared much. The chase, however, is quite hard and might take a few tries for you to get acquainted with the area you're running through. The chase requires you to memorize locations where you can refill Tattletail's needs while running through, and I found myself having fun with it. The developers also made the campaign free when they could have easily made you pay for it, and that's always a good thing to see. Overall, this mode has some fun surprises while not being all that scary.

31220924.review: I honestly like the game, I kept away from it for awhile because of the fandom, but I finnally decided to pick up this game. The game is a nice price of $5.00, which is pretty good for the game. The graphics are amazing for an indie game too! I only have 2 problems with the game. The first was how short the game was, I beat the entire game in about 36 minutes, this includes eggs and all. The other problem was how difficult Mama was to get away from, after I died about 6 times she wasn't scary anymore, she was more of just a problem. I would see the eyes, then I would slowly walk away then BAM! out of no where, Mama just kills me. I guess I just don't see how she works. But I managed to get past her after the second time because she spawned in a different location. But for the price of $5.00, this game did deliver some good scares and some childhood trauma! So I recommend it to anyone who likes horror and Furbys, and anyone who has $5.00 laying around!

31053111.review:
(Some spoilers ahead if you haven't play this game yet)

This was an interesting little horror game, it's not good or bad its just i don't know. Tattletail is clearly based off of Furbies and on the fact that they always looked creepy more than anything and not a bad concept managed to play the entire game and get all of the achivements in one go, but one of the things that i have agaisnt this game is the length of it.

Now i know it uses the "Five Nights" type of layout and considering the games setting that's understandble since its suppose to be five days before christmas and that's one of the neat things about the game is that it's a horror game thats set around christmas thats kind of cool (no pun indeeded). Back to the point though Tattletail is a neat little horror game based around an anoyying little toy that's constantly asking to be fed, bushed or recharged and your suppose to avoid the things "Mama". 

Mama Tattletail now thats one of this games mysteries, for instance what is she exactly? Is she possesed? Does she have a broken A.I.? Or is she simply suffering from a malfunction? either way the game doesnt exactly tell us the true reason why the mama tattletail was discontinued though its heavily hinted that it killed someone sometime before the game took place.

Though thats not the reason why I'm saying that i don't like the game that much i mean go ahead and play it for yourselfs and find out whats happening. The reason why i didn't enjoy it was simply because to me it wasn't all that fun. When i originaly saw this game through some youtubers i thought "hey this might be a neat little horror game to play" though after buying it and playing the entire thing and doing everything afterwords I just didn't enjoyed it that much as i thought i would. Overall im not saying its a bad game at all but to me it wasn't all that good either the story behind this game is that you play a small child who was to eger to wait for his presents and decided to open one of them up early and what that kid got was a very demanding little Furbe toy and his Creepy-Stalking Mama chasing him around the house at night. 

One more thing i got to note before ending this. What was with the ritual at the end of the game with all the tattletails? Was the Mama tattletail actually possesed by something? and "its" soul was connected to the VHS tape? I'm not really to sure where they were going with that idea but it seemed to of worked out i guess. Overall the games ok in my opinion and i might reccomened it to some of my friends but it isn't my cup of tea, I'd give it a 7.5/10 for some creativity with the Tattletail toys and the way that sound can actract the Mama Tattletail.

now, i'm just going to get all the obvious downsides out of the way:
-too easy
-too short
-default ending is unsatisfying
-doesn't answer the question it raises

Tattletale Review

Well...

Pros:

- You get to play as a (I think) 8 year old brat who gets to open his Christmas present early.
- Your mom had to much bee- I mean  candy and is too tired to help you. (Lets go with that.)
- Good graphics.
- YOU GET TO HAVE A DEMONIC FURBY!! (Did I spell that right?)
- The good ending is a good ending. (It's hard to get)

Cons:

- The graphics overpower my computer. (Don't buy if you have a sh** computer like mine.)
- The bad ending is bad. (It's easy to get.)
- Don't knock on moms door when mama is nearby. (jump scare)
- The game can be beaten in one sitting. (Too short)
- Jump scares get boring after one or two of them. (There is only one jump scare you can get)

Serious time 

One problem with the game is that there is a problem with the computer specs you need to have in order to play the game with a good frame rate. I was at a friends house and he wanted this game on his computer (Which is better than mine) We checked his computer specs and his mac overpowered the game's specs. After the download we started the game and the frame rate was awful! It was IMPOSSIBLE to play. (There were no background processes and we also tried turning down the resolution)
Do not buy unless you have a super great computer.

So I give Tattletale a 5/10

This is a short, clever little horror game that almost knows how to stay within its limitations: trapped within the confines of a small area (the player's house) and matched against a foe who has only basic attack patterns, Tattletail doesn't outstay its' welcome.

The game's central mechanic, a twist on the 'hide and seek' which sees the player have to remain silent while harbouring the incessantly chattering Tattletail toy, works well throughout the game's relatively short playtime. It's just a shame that, in its final act, the game lets the player peek a bit too far behind the curtain.

30486592.review:
I'll open this review by saying something quickly: Tattletail does not run very well. Others have this problem as well, you can get less than 14 FPS while playing. While it sounds bad, it's still playable and not a game-ruining issue.

Now that that is out of the way, on with the review!



So, everybody and their dog has heard of F.N.A.F (and don't worry, I won't compare it to it that much), Tattletail also utilises jumpscares as its primary source of scare, along with REALLY UNECESSARILY SCARY NOISES. Tattletail is spooky, fast and very unforgiving, especially with what you might expect. You play as a child, who like all of us, really REALLY wanted to open his / her presents, just days before Christmas. So, you sneak down to the basement, despite hearing a [b]LOT[/b] of things you shouldn't hear from the basement. And what's down there making all that noise?

You guessed it. Tattletail. He's the hot new toy hitting shelves just in time for Christmas! He eats real food, and goes through your fridge like it's full of chicken nuggets, but the sexy cutie Furby-like guy needs some serious styling as well, so be sure to keep him brushed! Don't forget his batteries (Not included) also need charging, or else he'll be no fun! He also likes to invite some "friends" over for a "party" sometimes.

This is a very short game, like FNAF, but it has a quirky charm to it: You have to take care of Tattletail. He is so frigging loud as well. Like, on par with that meme where Bart Simpson shouts "testing" into 50 megaphones all lined up. Tattletail is a cutie though, so you can kind of forgive him for being a loud fuzzy fuzzball.
I really don't want to say more, because this is a short game and you should find out for yourself, but I will say this:[b]


• Tattletail's needs are worth more than your own.
• Tattletail always knows.
• Mama is looking after you. [/b]



Expect surprises, spooks, and cutie fuzzy friends in this delightful indie horror!

When I first saw the trailer and gameplay for this game, I thought to myself "Oh, I can get through this game no problem! I understand its mechanics pretty well!"

I was wrong.

Fourth night, we're playing Hide n Seek with Tattletail's friend. Third time around. 1 1/2 minutes doesn't seem to long in the real world, but when it comes to games and trying to survive with a demonic Mama that wants to kick your ass so hard into next week, the stress kicks in.

The one thing I really enjoy about this game is the music and atmosphere set into the game. I was on the edge of my chair the entire time during the three games of Hide n Seek. Trying to keep your even-louder-and-cuter Furby as quiet as possible is the hardest thing, because the food meter drains faster than a single AA battery.

This game is worth playing. One of the few indie/horror games that I've really enjoyed so far.

30355677.review:
An incredibly scary game, I have to say.
This game is basically a knock-off versions of Furbies, but their Mama is possessed by Satan, who was captured by your mother in a vase.
When you break the vase, you awake Mama, and the horror begins.
The game's first two nights are simple, and teach you what to do:
On the first night:
-You learn about the ''Sound'' mechanic in this game;
-You learn the position of the fridge and the brush;
-You learn you need to feed and groom (Not reffering to the Outlast: Whistleblower one) the Tattletail.
On the second night you learn:
-About the recharger;
-About Mama;
-About the existance of a flashlight (Sadly it's a shake one).

The game is incredibly good, inflicting horror through the eerie sounds when you're hunted by Mama, and when she gets you, the jumpscare will be ten times as efficient.

The Tattletails are cute, and makes me wanna hug them, but I can't stand them when they run out of one of the meters, as it produces noises and makes Mama attack (She works on a sound-based attack system).

Plus, the ''Easter'' Eggs (Not really much of a game type of Easter Egg) have an impact on the game!

---UP UNTIL NOW, THERE WEREN'T MANY MAJOR SPOILERS, BUT THERE ARE HERE. FINISH THE GAME BEFORE CONTINUING---

Upon not collecting all the eggs/answered the call/both, Mama kills you, for the ritual was unsuccessful.

Upon getting all the eggs and not answering the phone, however, will reward you with your very own cuddly and lovely Tattletail! AND A GOLDEN FLASHLIGHT THAT DOESN'T HAVE THE LIFE SPAN OF A LAPTOP!

---WATCH OUT! DURING YOUR PRESENT OPENING AND KNOCKING ON YOUR MOTHER'S DOOR, AN EERIE MUSIC WILL PLAY. DO NOT PANIC UPON HEARING THE EERIE MUSIC---

Whilst the map itself is small, it still is pretty good.

---NO MORE SPOILERS FROM HERE---

Final verdict is 9/10. A well designed game that looks like a low budget horror game (FNAF), is not related to FNAF, and it's 5 BLOODY BUCKS!

I recommend this game for a short amount of fear and horror.

Unfortunately the first 4 of the 5 nights felt like a long tutorial, Mama looses her fear factor after the 5 or 6 time she catches you, and the ending was so pridictable that I allowed myself to fall for it because I was like there is no way it will end like this.

       That being said I did enjoy the game for what it was and would suggest giving the 3 to 5 hr game a go if your up to it.  If anyone is interest in checking out gameplay, I did a let's play you are welcome to check out. Click the Link ->      https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DNZA_PlYOqo

30046851.review:
So imagine this, its five days before Christmas, you're a little kid who just can't wait to open their presents. When you manage to build the courage and head towards the basement you find the gift that was at the top of your Christmas list... Tattletail. This little fucker is the shit of the town. The fatty eats all of your food, wants to be brushed constantly, and has the battery lifespan of a dying potato battery powering a clock. After you unbox the little furball he wants to get some food so he can become an even larger ball of fur.

Since you are a helpless little kid who can't say no to a toy who literally won't stop shouting about wanting a treat no matter how many times you hit it against the washing machine you give in. He eats through your refridgerator like a truck. Shortly after, he then needs to be groomed so he can be one sexy son of a bitch.

After using your mother's hairbrush she left conviently lying on the couch for the past few weeks you finally decide to shove the little guy back into his little box. As soon as he is back into his corporate prison, your phone starts ringing at 1:30 in the morning. Surprisingly enough, no one wakes up and you slip back into bed like the ninja you are.

The next night shit get serious. You wake up to hear this weird clunking sound in the basement again. Rushing downstairs to find out what the hell is making so much noise you find the little shit trying to kill itself inside of the same washing machine you constantly smashed it against to get it to stop shouting.

I would continue from here on out, but the adventures of Sir Random Parentless Child and Squire Furby-Knockoff is a heavily story driven game that truly needs to be experienced by the player.

29935481.review:
[h1]Tattletail, oh Tattletail.[/h1]

There are few games that I know from the moment I start playing the game, I'm going to love it.

Was Tattletail one of these games? Absolutely.

From the moment the game started, the music put me in a tense mood, and after a short intro screen, I was placed into a heavy atmosphere. The only direction I had was "Open your christmas present early"

If only I knew what that entailed.

---

Tattletail is frightening on many levels. It plays into my favourite type of fear, childhood horror. Anyone who was scared of furbies as a kid will undoubtedly be terrified of this game. Not afraid of furbies? Don't worry, you'll still be scared.

The sound design is what I love most about this game, the music is so unsettling, and the chase music is so intense. Even if you go through the whole game without getting jumpscared (Dying), you will still be on edge the whole game. From the music, to the noises "Mama" makes, and even Tattletail's voice acting, this game accomplishes what most horror titles don't. Actually being scary.

The story is another thing I love about Tattletail. I'm a big fan of hidden story/lore, so this game was quite the treat for me. Of course, if you enjoy plot without having to dig, the story may feel a bit lackluster. I can't say too much on my opinion of the story as we've seen so far as not too much has been found yet, but what we've seen so far is rather enticing. 

The gameplay mechanics are very fun, if not very well explained. But it doesn't take too long to get the hang of it. The mechanics work fluidly, and the controls are fluid and not clunky at all.

If I had to have any criticisms, it would definitely be performance. My computer can run most games fine, but Tattletail takes up a lot of resources. You better be prepared to close all background processes for a smooth run, or have a beefy computer.

Another gripe I had with the game was how short it was. If you're good at horror games, the game only takes about 2 hours to beat. Otherwise, I'd say 3 hours is the average. With such a great game, it leaves you aching for more when there is none (Here's to hoping for a sequel!)

Overall, an awesome game that will scare you out of your wits.



[b]Graphics:[/b] ★★★★☆

[b]Sound:[/b] ★★★★★

[b] [h1] Tattletail... [/h1] [/b]
Esse jogo é [b] MUITO [/b] bizarro. Ainda não zerei, e sinceramente, eu tô com medo de zerar. 


[b] [h1] História [/h1] [/b]
[list]
[*]  A história do jogo consiste em que, você é uma criança, e faltam 5 dias pro [b] Natal [/b], e você quer ver qual é seu presente antes do Natal pra poder brincar com ele, e seu presente é... o Tattletail! O bichinho mais fofo e adorável daquela época e que toda criança sonharia em ter um bicho daquele.

[*] Esse bichinho é tipo um cachorro, gato ou qualquer bicho de estimação, só que ele não faz cocô. Você pode alimentá-lo, pentear os pelinhos dele e colocá-lo para recarregar. Um [b] Tamagoshi [/b] real, vamos assim dizer.

[*] Fique atento aos barulhos. Use o fone de ouvido alto, mas não muito, pois é sempre bom redobrar a segurança, ou você estará sujeito a ter que repetir a noite, etc.

[*] Desde então, você brinca com o bichinho todas as noites... até o jogo realmente ficar [b] BIZARRO. [/b]
[/list]


[b] [h1] Dicas [/h1] [/b]
[list]

[*] Faça o mínimo de barulho possível.

[*] NÃO atenda o telefone.

[*] It's me! Tattletail!

[*] MANTÉM ESSE BICHO ALIMENTADO, PENTEADO E CARREGADO. ELE SÓ TE FERRA.

[*] Brush me! Brush me! Brush me!

[*] O próprio jogo te dá dica, ou seja, é recomendável que você saiba um pouco de inglês.
[/list]


[b] [h1] Pontos Positivos [/h1] [/b]
[list]

[*] Jogo bem feito e bem desenvolvido, com uma ideia simplesmente genial, com estilo VHS antigo.

[*] O jogo relembra infâncias de muitos, até mesmo os que nasceram entre 2000-2005, pois tem o ''Tattletail'', que lembra o [b] Furby [/b], que já foi o sonho de muitos.

[*] Esse jogo faz você criar estratégias próprias, tipo, eu e meu amigo temos estrátegias diferentes, mas ambas funcionam, pois nós arrumamos um jeitinho de conseguir passar o dia, etc.

[*] Esse jogo lembra bastante o [b] ''Five Nights At Freddy's'' [/b], que é um jogo bom, porém o Tattletail deixa você andar pela casa, mas mesmo assim, você tem que ficar atento aos seus lados, pois isso fará MUITA diferença no seu jogo.
[/list]


[b] [h1] Pontos Negativos [/h1] [/b]
[list]

[*] Bastante difícil 

[*] Dá bastante medo [b] (MINHA OPINIÃO) [/b]

[*] Poderia ter gráficos melhores, porém, os que já estão lá já são bons

[*] Poderia ter uma história toda envolvida.


Sem esquecer, essas são as configurações [b] MÍNIMAS [/b] necessárias. 

[code] 
[b] SO [/b] : Windows 7 ou melhor (W8, W8.1, W10)
[b] Processador [/b] : 2.0 GHz Processador Dual Core
[b] Memória [/b] : 2 GB de RAM
[b] Placa de vídeo [/b] : ''Cartão'' de Vídeo com 512MB de VRAM
[b] DirectX [/b] : Versão 9.0
[b] Armazenamento [/b] : 300 MB de espaço disponível
[/code]

Super recomendo esse jogo! Menos pra pessoinhas com menos de 12 aninhos.

[b] [h1] 9/10 [/h1] [/b]

At first glance I tought this was a comedy game; but once I watched the second half of the trailer I realized this was a horror game and not any horror game, one of the best.

PROS:
-	Creepy atmosphere. (I decided to turn off the lights to play and 5 min,  later I turner them on!)
-	The VHS tape!
-	Interesting gameplay mechanics (Feeding and grooming your Tattletail keeps it from making noise and making you get caught by Mama Tattletail.)
-	Missions are based on completing different tasks.
-	The setting is small but you can actually make lots of stuff.
-	Tons of secret stuff hidden in the game; watch YouTube videos on this game; the house has a secret room, the VHS has a numerical code which can be manipulated with several numerical sequences shown in the game, etc.

CONS:
-	Very short (5 Missions, only 2 are actual missions, 2 are tutorials and the last is too short)
-	No GamePad support.
-	Objectives may be confusing at some times.
-	Bad ending could have been more impacting

29558302.review:
Five bucks for a small game these days is pretty steep. Games like this are usually free on site like Itchio and Gamejolt, so is this worth your money?

I suppose that depends on how you approach the game. I certainly enjoyed my time with this.

The game is from a child's perspective, and takes place in the days following Christmas, which is a topic and style not usually tackled in horror games. The graphics are subpar at best, but the atmosphere created from the first moments of the game really set the tone for later.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g2MJMVpyObs

*SPOILERS FOR THE STORY PAST THIS POINT ON*

Once Mama is introduced, everything is thrown on its head. The house becomes as wicked and scary as the buildup suggests, and more than likely you are going to die from sheer confusion and terror.

This leads me to one of my biggest problems with the game: Mama's kill method.

From the first time Mama is introduced, it seems as though her A.I. is programmed like the usual "She can't see you, but she can hear you" deal. Well, that seems the case, but I suffered from dying to what seemed like nothing. Apparently she can just warp all over the place, and if you're not prepared she can insta-kill you out of nowhere. Luckily the game supplements this with constantly saving checkpoints in the night.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X8ghaZT6Cn0

The Tattletails alsohave a Hunger, Battery, and Brush meter that gradually decreases as they away from the things that regenerate those meters. I felt as though this was unneccessary, as I never encountered a time when the Tattletails yelling put me in peril.

The ending of the game is where I lost interest, however, as the last night was more tedious as it was scary. By this time I had already gotten the shock factor of dying out of the way (As my FNAF experience has conditioned me for) and dying was an annoyance rather than a terrifying plight,

Oh? But didn't I say that the game put up checkpoints every so often in case you died? I did. The last night puts checkpoints too, though only after surviving long, seemingly random Mama encounters, and fetch quests.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZnwD_6vKFfM

The story seemed unique, but several factors (Such as my parents not existing, though that could have been the horror trope) marred the experience I was ready to be over with. 

The ending was lackluster, but I have et to get the "Secret Ending" I think you receive after obtaining all the easter eggs, so perhaps the True Ending isn't as bad.

Nevertheless, give this game a go if you're into Five Nights at Freddy's style games, or for a cool twist on the child's perspective/Christmas horror story genre.

29427556.review:
When I first heard of this game, I said: "Oh. A Furby-themed horror? That sounds a little boring."
Boy, was I wrong.

Tattletail is a game that's based around a Furby-type virtual pet called a "Baby Talking Tattletail". You're tasked with grooming it, feeding it and charging it's battery, all whilst avoiding the grasp of it's bloodthirsty mama in a small, dark house. You are given only a flashlight to protect yourself, and while this might sound like the typical "Run away from the baddie in the dark" horror game, it's far from it.

Tattletail happens to be the one thing that will get you killed. When hiding from Mama, you'll have to be sure you've got plenty of light, Tattletail hates the dark, as well as having to keep him fed, clean and charged at the same time.

The story is pretty simple. YOu're a small, curious and naughty child that opened their Christmas present early, and inside was a Baby Talking Tattletail, the newest from the WayGetters electronics line of products. As you tend to the thing, you'll start being hunted by the previously discontinued "Mama Tattletail", who is no longer available to purchase for unknown reason.

Despite the story being so straightforward, the gameplay is something you'll NEVER forget.

tl;dr: Buy the game because spooky Furby hide and seek in the dark. It's fun.

10/10 IGN Would fear Furbies again.

My friend bought this game for me after I saw a video on youtube and fell in LOVE with the Tattletail toy and I absolutely LOVE IT!!! I streamed it for my friends and played through the levels in about an hour and a half. I still need to go back for some achievements!

Gameplay wise I am very glad for the great checkpoint mechanic, it will put you back at a good place to continue from without getting too frustrated if you screw anything up while you learn the game. It was super fun, and I was more scared from Mama staring at me from a dark place than the jumpscares from her. This game is very good with its ambient horror, musical cues, etc. It all plays together very well to make this game a great experience! I love it so much!

The only issue I have is volumetric lighting not working, instead displaying some really awkward white boxes of light and I'm running the game on an AMD RX 480. This isn't really a huge issue, just something weird.

The game itself doesn't feel too repetitive to me, more like you're just running around the same house you've lived in for, y'know, your entire childhood, type feeling. You don't get to interact with too much, and that adds to the feeling of knowing the house too well. It is something I wish though, for more stuff to interact with, if it becomes something for an update in the future. I wanna touch and/or break anything I can get my little baby hands on, even if Mama gets mad.

Tattletail is a great game, and a great looking toy that I wish I could own!

29409247.review:
Tattletail is a bit of a strange game to me as far as gameplay, mechanics and human psychology goes.

Is this game scary? yes, yes it is... for a while. It can be very unsettling the first time you play tattletail and without saying any spoilers, can linger for quite a while.  I personally think the game to a certain point doesn't keep it's scare factor as you do get used to it very quickly. But with problems with the game, as glitches are concerned, there are quite a few here and there.

1st, would be Mama herself. Don't get me wrong i do like how she attacks you, but it's HOW she attacks you... let me explain. Mama only attacks you if you make too much noise (or if you run into her like an idiot... like me), it's so scary to find her red glowing eyes cutting through the darkness... and thats it. She does attack you if you can't get away from her but for some weird reason, i had ran into Mama, she's staring at me, speaks, Tattletail freaks out from the darkness (and hungry)..... but nothing happens. i was just staring at her till she goes away. I even had a friend on my phone watching me play it and we couldn't stop wondering why she hasn't attacked me yet.

2nd, this may be a spoiler or an exploit so stop reading this one if you haven't played yet. The timing of Mama coming after you when you're either making too much noise or Tattletail never shutting up. whenever i make too much noise with my flashlight or running steps, she can find me like im ringing a dinner bell. But strangly enough, i had Tattletail running out of power (sounds like this fish low on batteries https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dHchmWsrfUo ), but Mama was coming at me as if she was either very lazy or switched to moving in a wheel chair.

3rd, im not sure if this is a glitch but something i've noticed. One day i had Mama killing me over and over because i was playing hide and seek with a Tattletale, but i respawn to the last time i spoke with that Tattletail. however, near the end of the game, i had to do a long list of tasks, but when Mama kills me, i had to start al the tasks over on that day.

If i had to sum it all up, it is a great game... enough said.

29307877.review:
Tattletail is a short horror game that is, in my opinion, quite enjoyable despite its simplicity. It takes an absurd concept (like other games in recent memory) and turns it into something terrifying by becoming neither too serious nor too silly. If you're looking for the scariest game of the decade, this game probably isn't what you're looking for. If you're looking for the most mundane horror game available, this game probably isn't what you're looking for. If you're looking for something fun and creepy to play for about an hour, this game might be what you're looking for! The gameplay consists of egg collection, red-light-green-light from hell, pet care simulation, and irresponsible parenting. Merry Christmas!

PROS: 

probably wont give you a heart-attack
polished environments and mechanics
your little friend is kind of cute actually
you get free gifts such as fingernails, hair, etc.
environmentally friendly flashlights

CONS:

probably wont give you a heart-attack
relatively short
might curse your computer

29298413.review:
This was a gift from someone who knows the evil that Furbys possess. That same person and I had an experience with an evil Furby when we were kids. This Furby was creepy as hell. This was right when Furbys blew up in the US.  No one knew how evil they were yet. This thing would randomly start talking, asking for food and moving around by itself. One night, during a sleepover around the holiday season, this Furby decided to wake us up by perching itself on top of a bookshelf (no idea how the hell it got there) and screaming about how much it loved us. That is when we knew... Our Furby was possessed.

Long story short. I sold it on eBay a few years later as a "demonically possessed Furby". Made 50 bucks and never saw it again.

So this game really hit close to home for me. The biggest difference between this game and my life was that 
1. Our Furby never reproduced on its own.                                                                                                      
2. We went out of our way to not interact with it.                                                                                       
3. It did not have a mother (that we knew of).

Honestly this game was fun. It was creepy at first but it does wear off. There is not really an effective "jump scare" game but the ambiance and mood is what makes this creepy. 

Gameplay- 4/5 It's not very hard to play and the controls are simple. Could be better but for what it is, not bad.

Sound- 5/5 This is where the game shines. The sound effects are good. The "tattletail" its mother the cassette audio playing . Very creepy stuff. 

Graphics- 4/5 Not bad for a Unity game. First person 3d. Reminds me of a slightly more modern Source game. The effects could be better but for what the game costs and what it is, it's good.

Overall- 4/5. For what it costs, the amount you'll make back on trading cards (Jan 2017) and the game itself, this was fun. It's not very long. You can figure it out and beat it pretty fast. What I liked at first was the ambiance and the 'chill' effect. It does not really give you a lot of info to start out with, but keeps adding reasons to do or NOT to do certain things. On the contrary though, it tries to be a puzzle game at certain points and fails at this because it gives you the player too little info to solve it (at least at first)

One of my favorite aspects was the mother trying to kill you, not because the jump scare was good (it wasn't BTW) but because it was fun to hide from it. You had to strategies to ensure your survival. There is a flashlight, a hunger meter,groom meter and battery meter that all need to be maintained as well as the ability to move around without making noise. 

My least favorite was the repetitiveness of it. Even when adding new challenges, the effect wore off and stopped being creepy and started playing like any other game. Once you figured out how to avoid the mother or when the 'spooky' factor wore off, the game dulls quickly. Another issue is that during the first nights, you aren't punished for anything. The items you "have to do" have no negative effect on the game if you don't do them. You just can't progress. The game is trying to introduce you to the mechanics but honestly it wastes time doing it. It could just give you a walkthrough tutorial and then give you more game to play.

It's only $5 so I still feel that's worth it, even if you only get an hour out if it. Buy it if you liked Five Nights at Freddy's.

29293912.review:

Yet another game to add to the pile of unity games that ask for money yet offer nothing overly original.

For 5 bucks, I can recommend this for kids and those who like unoriginal horror. However ultimately this is just another game to make a quick dollar and leave you pissed you that you could have spent it on something more worthwhile.

29289595.review: While short, this game is totally worth it. Tattletail is a game built around atmosphere and nostalgia. It offer's a wide assortment of different mini-games for each night instead of keeping to a formula like a certain game involving killer animatronics. Which was what I was personally expecting Tattletail to be like due to that franchises popularity. Let's say I was pleasantly surprised. The VHS aesthetic is VERY creepy and adds a lot to the horror factor. The voice acting is fantastic and lets you grow close to your Furby friend whenever he's not getting you in trouble. But with every great thing, there are always flaws. Let's start with the obvious one; the clunky controls. My main issue with it is the mouse sensitivity. While the newest "The Gift" Update has improved upon the problem, a 4 on the sensitivity scale still feels like a 10. For example, while playing on default mouse sensitivity whenever I simply tapped my mouse, the main character did a 360. This next one is more of a personal con. I think that Tattletails individual needs bars go down to fast. Most times whenever I was trying to hide from Mama Tattletail, presumably away from the places that'll restore one of Tattletail's needs, one of the furry little s*@#'s needs will drop to zero which will trigger him to start making a lot of noise that'll attract Mama quickly. For this one, I have some simple resolutions that I'm sure not only I want. Maybe if there were more places to restore Tattletail's needs, it'll make it just a tad bit easier not to be caught. Or, obviously, just lowering the digression speed of Tattletail's needs. That being said, I really love this game and I want to see it blossom but I fear it'll be looked down upon do to these issues. Hopefully my critiques will be resolved or improved upon.

29288345.review:
[h1] TL;DR [/h1] 

[b] [i] Tattletail is basically what you get when you cross Five Nights at Freddy’s theming, Slender’s gameplay, and an 80s VHS aesthetic with complete and utter tedium. [/i] [/b]

Considering this review is getting voted down, I'm pretty curious what people enjoyed about the game. Let's forget the annoying characters, the only mechanics in the game are fetch this, avoid Mama, and keep Tattletail fed, brushed, and charged. The problem is, none of these are fun. Mama is annoying and extremely easy to avoid as long as RNG doesn't decide to screw you over, the fetch quests are very repetetive, and the survival mechanic is basically nothing but a chore. It never killed me, it only made me stop and walk around getting them filled up, bored out of my mind.

29284163.review:
What can I say? For $5, it's pretty much the quality and experience one would expect. The game mechanics were incredibly simple and easy to pick up... and there really isn't a lot of depth to the game: just don't get caught. I was a bit put out with the inconsistent frame rate, as this can make eluding Mama harder in the unfair/frustrating way than a genuine game difficulty way.

Don't get me wrong... I can appreciate simple, short games (expect to finish it in ~1-1.5 hours). It allowed me a casual distraction from the work I should probably be getting done. However, if you're looking for a legitimately frightening horror game experience, I suggest you look elsewhere. This is basically a mashup of FNAF and Among the Sleep... which isn't necessarily a bad thing as long as you know what you're getting for your $5.

29157177.review:
Tattletail is a relatively short, but fun horror game.  The basic premise is maybe you're a bit too eager for your Christmas gift.  So you go ahead and peak a few days early - it's a Fur... Tattletail! The latest and greatest in robotic toys!  So you take the little fella' out of it's package and play with it.  And boy is it needy!  It wants food.  It wants to be brushed.  It needs to be charged. Doesn't care much for the dark, either.  So it'll nag you until you take care of it.  Oh yeah - it's Mamma is really, really protective.  So watch out for her!  

So for around five dollars or so you'll get about an hours worth of entertainment. Maybe a bit less if you rush.  A bit more if you try to get all the achievements.  There are also spiffy trading cards - which as of writing this review are going for quite a bit compared to most cards.  

https://youtu.be/OGmnsYUNv8Q

29156657.review:
Tattletail, although obviously inspired by FNaF, gave me a much more enjoyable experience than any of the FNaF games.
***SPOILERS BEYOND THIS POINT***

Pros:
+Great atmosphere, keeps you on the edge of your seat
+Tattletail only adds to this atmosphere. While creepy in the beginning, he quickly becomes your best friend in the fight against mama
+Keeps you wondering about the world and the backstory behind Tattletail
+The jumpscare's sound isn't boosted +50db above every other sound in the game (this was my main problem with FNaF)
+Text effects are flashy and appealing to the eye, along with other smooth and quick animations that add to the urgency of some situations
+Voices and other sounds are great in keeping you in the world
+I had no idea how much of an impact making sound had until day 3

Cons:
-Mechanics of Mama are difficult to understand (this one has been made a lot better with the gift update)
-I spent like 2 hours trying to see if there was any way for me to get past the fence gate in the back (there wasn't)

Overall, very enjoyable horror game; atmosphere was good, effects were smooth, tattletail was lovable, and the best part was being scared of the jumpscare instead of being scared of the earbursting sound that came with it. Really hope the devs keep updating this one and let us in Tattletail's world.

29123411.review:
So I've been hearing about this game a lot recently and decided to give it a try since I rarely play horror games these days.  I'm more a Silent Hills type of guy.  I'm glad I gave this a chance because it's a pretty fun and unsettling experience to be honest.  

The sound design is pretty amazing and had me going "Nope!" several times.  I appreciate that it isn't the jumpscare that gets to me but rather the buildup to it.  As a soon-to-be 30 year old, I got a nice bit of nostalgia from this game and I love the aesthetic and overall design of the environment and faux Tattletail commercial.  

The game mechanics are fun and add to the tension because you're given tasks to perform but you still have to keep track of Tattletail's needs.  He must be groomed, fed, and charged every so often and if you fail to keep up with that...well...you'll see.  

The game seems rather short but it's fun for a quick horror romp and something different from the usual horror fare around here.  The price point is perfect for this becuase I can tell the developer put in a lot of work and care but they also realize the content and length play a large factor as far as what the charge customers.  

Check out my somewhat vulger playthrough of the first few nights of Tattletail!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=838075428

29120559.review:
If you're a product of the 80s or 90s, you'll almost certainly remember when Furby hit the market and the mass hysteria that every kid and their dog had in wanting to own one. Hell, I was one of them. 

If you ever had a Furby, then you'll undoubtedly remember the first time he woke you up in the middle of the night, demanding food and telling you that he wanted to play, as his little mechanical beak mouth ground its way open and closed, open and closed, open and closed. The cold sweat dripping slowly down the sides of your temples, as you hid under your blanket thinking that as long as you couldn't see Furby, Furby couldn't see you. Yeah. You know EXACTLY what I'm talking about. Don't you?

Tattletail is basically this traumatic period of your childhood life, recreated in game form. The only difference is that this Furby, or rather this Furby's mother, is a little more dangerous than the dubious robo-pets we all used to have in our bedrooms as kids. Don't let her find you, cause you know what'll happen. Oh, you don't know? Well, I can't tell you. Don't wanna be a tattletale!

-------------------------------------------

If you think this game might be for you, you're welcome to take a look at my first 3 nights in the video below -
